name: NPR
text:
Two influential reports suggest that reduced global oil consumption and low prices will continue well into 2021 ‚Äî if not longer.

"The path forward is treacherous," one advisory body warned.
https://t.co/qAxLbJWKqq

name: NPR
text:
Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Wolf slammed Republicans for celebrating a federal judge's ruling that called some of the state's since-lifted pandemic restrictions unconstitutional.
https://t.co/tbrFuDLfOJ

name: NPR
text:
Senators pressed a Google executive Tuesday over whether the tech giant wields too much power over advertisers and publishers in the digital ad market. It comes amid increasing scrutiny of the company's dominance.
https://t.co/qpUofWOvHR

name: NPR
text:
.@roughly is back with a new season, starting September 16th.  ‚Äì ‚ÄúSchool of Scandal‚Äù edition. This fall, stories of people shaking things up, sometimes in unconventional ways. It might get dirty, but sometimes that‚Äôs just what you gotta do. 
https://t.co/JdhzD9JUM9

name: NPR
text:
Facebook is launching a page focused on climate change facts with "authoritative information about what is happening to our climate, how it's changing," the company's vice president says.
https://t.co/OXkyGADOB4

name: NPR
text:
Most D.C.-area private workers will likely work from home until next summer, according to a survey of hundreds of employers. Many firms cited worries about public transit safety.
https://t.co/ETQmLMtbvE

name: NPR
text:
The Sun has passed into a new 11-year activity cycle ‚Äî but scientists predict the new cycle's intensity, which will peak in 2025, should be almost identical to the last.
https://t.co/DNVhta491v

name: NPR
text:
60 years ago, a company introduced a computer program that used polling data to predict the impact of political messages. 

At the time, many decried it as a threat to democracy.

But, says historian Jill Lepore, "that's now what our politics has become."
https://t.co/SwGo2ypC5O

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: Ever been through a hard heartbreak? Arlo Parks' (@arloparks) songwriting taps into those familiar (and often uncomfortable) feels. Watch her Tiny Desk (home) concert recorded at home in London. https://t.co/g0AhRPA3Ka

name: NPR
text:
Netflix's CEO argues a creative workplace needs as few policies and rules as possible to thrive ‚Äî and credits the company's meteoric rise to its unorthodox workplace culture.

Others say it can be ruthless and transparent "to the point of dysfunction." 
https://t.co/DCEJq87rTT

name: NPR
text:
OPEC predicts total oil demand in 2020 will be slashed by nearly 10%.

But that's nowhere near the large-scale pivot away from fossil fuels that scientists say is necessary to fight climate change.
https://t.co/nZzukGafKf

name: NPR
text:
A new book by photographer Janna Ireland showcases the work of Paul R. Williams, the first Black architect in the American West, who believed "good design wasn't just for the rich."
https://t.co/2f6PtXli7z

name: NPR
text:
Forecasters are closely monitoring a pair of weather systems that threaten to deliver more damage in what has already been an active hurricane season. Hurricane Paulette is rolling toward Bermuda while Tropical Storm Sally is moving toward the Gulf Coast.
https://t.co/NZyDfs26y5

name: NPR
text:
A simple DIY project accidentally launched Sandy Chilewich‚Äôs 40-year career as a designer, entrepreneur, and creator of the now-famous @chilewich placemat. 

The story is this week‚Äôs episode of @HowIBuiltThis with @GuyRaz . Listen now.
https://t.co/2lClUIx7cx

name: NPR
text:
We last spoke with Soumana Saley in 2018. Now he's facing a tough year because of the pandemic. He lost his factory job and craft fairs have gone on hiatus. Despite the hard times, he's committed to sending money to support his school in his native Niger.
https://t.co/QToSQFuUvb

name: NPR
text:
Top Democrats are calling for an investigation after a whistleblower alleged hysterectomies are being performed on immigrants at a detention center in Georgia.

Other accusations include shredding medical requests and refusing to test detainees for COVID.
https://t.co/HSMNpbeTmQ

name: NPR
text:
The vast majority of children dying from COVID-19 in the U.S. are Hispanic, Black and/or Native American, a new CDC report finds.
https://t.co/JXmxF9Vh2y

name: NPR
text:
U.S. retail sales in August grew a tepid 0.6%.

Here's where shoppers were spending last month, compared with July:

üìà Restaurants, bars: +4.7%
üìà Clothing, accessories: +2.9%
üìà Furniture stores: +2.1%
üìà Home improvement, gardening stores: +2%
https://t.co/H9uDPzr3hK

name: NPR
text: Scam artists, political anarchists, are terms that have been used to describe the Dorr brothers. The No Compromise team investigates just who these brothers are and why political leaders have several issues with their non-profit businesses. https://t.co/X0b5mtdrth

name: NPR
text:
Hurricane Sally made landfall as a Category 2 storm on Wednesday morning ‚Äî bringing 105 mph winds and the threat of historic flooding. Some isolated areas in its path could see nearly 3 feet of rain.
https://t.co/pV254O1mVg

name: NPR
text:
A group of celebrities say they're taking a 24-hour break from Facebook and Instagram to protest Facebook's failure to control disinformation and hate speech on the platform.
https://t.co/rDuJZQV3Dn

name: NPR
text:
72% of the country's Latino households report facing serious financial problems during the pandemic, a new NPR poll finds. That's double the percentage of whites who report the same.
https://t.co/nPrfbvLqm9

name: NPR
text:
Top congressional Democrats are calling for the DHS inspector general to investigate whistleblower claims of insufficient medical care and high rates of hysterectomies being performed on immigrants at a privately owned detention center in Georgia.
https://t.co/G0Cfue8rnA

name: NPR
text:
As U.S. employers shed millions of permanent, full-time jobs, people are increasingly having to turn to freelancing as a means of survival.

And some experts say that shift is likely to continue.
https://t.co/6En9CgXM0x

name: NPR
text:
Tenants across the U.S. are still being forced out of their homes during the pandemic, advocates say ‚Äî despite bans on evictions.

In L.A., a woman's landlord shut off water and gas to force tenants out, then reportedly tore up the kitchen floor and sink.
https://t.co/U9gvGoKxBb

name: NPR
text:
The Big Ten Conference now says it will return to football in October.

The reversal comes about a month after Commissioner Kevin Warren wrote that postponing the season was based on guidance from medical experts and would not be revisited.
https://t.co/T6XbG2T61M

name: NPR
text:
Nearly 3 billion birds have died since 1970 in North America.

Declines in insect populations on the continent could have a huge effect on the feathered creatures, ornithologist Martha Desmond says. https://t.co/XtqoLZGMtk

name: NPR
text:
Testifying before a Senate panel, top Trump administration health officials said a COVID-19 vaccine isn't likely to be widely available until next spring or summer.
https://t.co/hP9UkbBs8Y

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: President Trump is back to holding massive, in-person rallies. Joe Biden is holding much smaller in-person and virtual events.

Here's a look at how their campaigns differ right now: https://t.co/eCssrYnlrY

name: NPR
text:
The backup driver behind the wheel of an autonomous Uber car that fatally struck an Arizona woman in 2018 has been charged with negligent homicide.
https://t.co/7dhDIJBGNz

name: NPR
text:
Stanley Crouch, the lauded and fiery jazz critic, has died at age 74. His engagement with American culture spanned more than five decades and numerous mediums.
https://t.co/kUbu4zPVjN

name: NPR
text:
The Federal Reserve left interest rates near zero on Wednesday and pledged that it would continue to support an economic recovery that appears to be losing steam.
https://t.co/VAf3OSUGZS

name: NPR
text:
Hoping to overturn a lower court ruling that blocked its attempt to exclude unauthorized immigrants from the census numbers used to reallocate seats in Congress, the Trump administration is turning to the Supreme Court.  
https://t.co/dBpTVOU4wM

name: NPR
text:
RT @Roughly: New episode! 

What happens when government censorship is used by celebrity superfans to get revenge?

@Roughly joins @EmilyZFeng on a deep dive into China‚Äôs ‚Äúreporting culture‚Äù & how a boy band star found himself at the center of it. #XiaoZhan 

https://t.co/9JDC0pXXHl

name: NPR
text:
Faulting the federal and state governments for not doing more to ease the financial burden on cities like his, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio says he and other staff will take an unpaid furlough week. 
https://t.co/0OnwO35ZL3

name: NPR
text: RT @NPRKelly: The CDC now confirming what other officials have been quietly trying to tell us: a vaccine won't be widely available until "the second or third quarter" of next year. https://t.co/XiDfMce6Hk

name: NPR
text:
Rosie Torres recalls hearing Jon Stewart say it took 5 seconds for police and firefighters to respond on 9/11.

When she asked if he'd lend his voice to veterans exposed to toxic burn pits, "that's the amount of time Jon... took to respond to our ask." https://t.co/e17c23BzQp
